publication milestones were reached at the journal that has published the article. Where applicable, activities on preceding journals at which the article was previously under consideration are not shown (for instance submission, revisions, rejection).</p><p class=\"u-margin-xs-bottom\">The publication milestones include:</p><ul class=\"key-dates-help-list u-margin-m-bottom u-padding-s-left\"><li><span class=\"u-text-italic\">Received</span>: The date the article was originally submitted to the journal.</li><li><span class=\"u-text-italic\">Revised</span>: The date the most recent revision of the article was submitted to the journal. Dates corresponding to intermediate revisions are not shown.</li><li><span class=\"u-text-italic\">Accepted</span>: The date the article was accepted for publication in the journal.</li><li><span class=\"u-text-italic\">Available online</span>: The date a version of the article was made available online in the journal.</li><li><span class=\"u-text-italic\">Version of Record</span>: The date the finalized version of the article was made available in the journal.</li></ul><p>More information on publishing policies can be found on the <a class=\"anchor anchor-secondary u-display-inline anchor-underline\" href=\"https://www.elsevier.com/about/policies-and-standards/publishing-ethics\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"anchor-text-container\"><span class=\"anchor-text\">Publishing Ethics Policies</span></span></a> page. class="PageDivider"></div></div><div class="Extras" id="toc-extras"><h2 class="u-h4">Extras (1)</h2><ol class="u-padding-s-bottom"><li class="toc-list-entry-outline-padding"><a class="anchor u-truncate-anchor-text anchor-primary anchor-icon-left anchor-with-icon" href="#mmc1" data-aa-button="sd:product:journal:article:type=anchor:region=outline:name=sdf" title="Multimedia component class="PageDivider"></div></div></div></div><article class="col-lg-12 col-md-16 pad-left pad-right u-padding-s-top" lang="en"><div class="Publication" id="publication"><div class="publication-brand u-display-block-from-sm"><a class="anchor u-display-flex anchor-primary" href="/journal/materials-chemistry-and-physics" title="Go to Materials Chemistry and Physics on ScienceDirect"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text"><img class="publication-brand-image" text-xs u-margin-xs-bottom access-type-label-only"><div class="AccessLabel"><span class="access-indicator"></span>Full text access</div></div><section class="ReferencedArticles"></section><section class="ReferencedArticles"></section><div class="PageDivider border-black-mobile"></div><div class="Abstracts u-font-serif" id="abstracts"><div class="abstract author-highlights" id="abs0020" lang="en"><h2 class="section-title u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Highlights</h2><div id="abssec0020"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="abspara0020"><ul class="list"><li class="react-xocs-list-item"><span class="list-label">â€¢</span><span class="list-content"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0010">Nanoflower (NF)â€“Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub><span>@rGO was prepared using a facile one-step <a href="/topics/materials-science/hydrothermal-synthesis" title="Learn more about hydrothermal method from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">hydrothermal method</a>.</span></div></span></li><li class="react-xocs-list-item"><span class="list-label">â€¢</span><span class="list-content"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0015">NFâ€“Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>@rGO was applied to SIBs as a promising anode material.</div></span></li><li class="react-xocs-list-item"><span class="list-label">â€¢</span><span class="list-content"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0020">Superior electrochemical properties of NFâ€“Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>@rGO electrodes were exhibited.</div></span></li><li class="react-xocs-list-item"><span class="list-label">â€¢</span><span class="list-content"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0025">The Na<sup>+</sup>&nbsp;storage mechanism of NFâ€“Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>@rGO was investigated by CV and GITT tests.</div></span></li></ul></div></div></div><div class="abstract author" id="abs0010" lang="en"><h2 class="section-title u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Abstract</h2><div id="abssec0010"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="abspara0010"><span>Sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) gradually become ideal substitutes to lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) as a result of higher applicability in new-generation energy storage system. However, the controlled preparation of superior electrode materials for obtaining high-performance SIBs remains a challenge. In this study, a composite structure comprising three-dimensional <a href="/topics/chemical-engineering/nanoflower" title="Learn more about nanoflower from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">nanoflower</a> Sb</span><sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub><span> and <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/reduced-graphene-oxide" title="Learn more about reduced graphene oxide from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">reduced graphene oxide</a><span> (rGO) was successfully manufactured by applying a <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/hydrothermal-synthesis" title="Learn more about hydrothermal method from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">hydrothermal method</a><span> as an emerging <a href="/topics/materials-science/anode-material" title="Learn more about anode material from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">anode material</a> for SIBs. Nanoflower Sb</span></span></span><sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub><span>@rGO exhibited excellent <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/electrochemical-performance" title="Learn more about electrochemical performance from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrochemical performance</a><span><span>, yielding 544.8 mAh/g at a rate of 100&nbsp;mA/g, and sustained stability in the later 200 cycles, which was 75.4% of the initial value for the specific capacity. Even the current density is 2000&nbsp;mA/g, a specific energy capacity of 433.4 mAh/g was obtained. The <a href="/topics/materials-science/sodium" title="Learn more about sodium from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">sodium</a> storage mechanism was explored using </span><a href="/topics/materials-science/cyclic-voltammetry" title="Learn more about cyclic voltammetry from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">cyclic voltammetry</a> at different sweep speeds to clearly point out the electrochemical process of forming nanoflower Sb</span></span><sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>@rGO. The results indicate that the high performance is ascribed to the particular flower-like three-dimensional structure, which provides cache space for Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub><span> volume expansion during charge/discharge, while the addition of rGO effectively improves the overall <a href="/topics/materials-science/electrical-conductivity" title="Learn more about electrical conductivity from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrical conductivity</a> of the electrode. This work furnishes a new insight into the construction of specially structured anode materials to promote the development of SIBs.</span></div></div></div><div class="abstract graphical" id="abs0015"><h2 class="section-title u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Graphical abstract</h2><div id="abssec0015"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="abspara0015"><span class="display"><figure class="figure text-xs" id="undfig1"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S025405842300545X-ga1.jpg" height="195" alt="Image 1"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S025405842300545X-ga1_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (379KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (379KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S025405842300545X-ga1.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span></figure></span></div></div></div></div><ul id="issue-navigation" class="issue-navigation u-margin-s-bottom u-bg-grey1"><li class="previous move-left u-padding-s-ver u-padding-s-left"><a class="button-alternative button-alternative-tertiary u-display-flex button-alternative-icon-left" href="/science/article/pii/S0254058423005679"><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 54 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-left"><path d="M1 61l45-45 7 7-38 38 38 38-7 7z"></path></svg><span class="button-alternative-text-container"><span class="button-alternative-text">Previous <span class="extra-detail-1">article</span><span class="extra-detail-2"> in issue</span></span></span></a></li><li class="next move-right u-padding-s-ver u-padding-s-right"><a class="button-alternative button-alternative-tertiary u-display-flex button-alternative-icon-right" href="/science/article/pii/S0254058423004492"><span class="button-alternative-text-container"><span class="button-alternative-text">Next <span class="extra-detail-1">article</span><span class="extra-detail-2"> in issue</span></span></span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 54 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-right"><path d="M1 99l38-38L1 23l7-7 45 45-45 45z"></path></svg></a></li></ul><div class="Keywords u-font-serif"><div id="kwrds0010" class="keywords-section"><h2 class="section-title u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Keywords</h2><div id="kwrd0010" class="keyword"><span>Anode material</span></div><div id="kwrd0015" class="keyword"><span>Antimony sulfide</span></div><div id="kwrd0020" class="keyword"><span>Nanoflower</span></div><div id="kwrd0025" class="keyword"><span>Sodium-ion batteries</span></div></div></div><div class="Body u-font-serif" id="body"><div><section id="sec1"><h2 id="sectitle0035" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">1. Introduction</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0035"><span>As the primary power supply device, lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) have been widely employed in portable communication equipment and new energy vehicles as secondary rechargeable batteries thanks to their high <a href="/topics/materials-science/energy-density" title="Learn more about energy density from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">energy density</a> and exceptional cycling stability [</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib1" name="bbib1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[1]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib2" name="bbib2" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib2"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[2]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib3" name="bbib3" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib3"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[3]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib4" name="bbib4" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib4"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[4]</span></span></a><span>]. Nevertheless, LIBs are not suitable for long-term energy storage solution restricted to the resource scarcity and uneven distribution of lithium element. Recently, sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) are emerging as a significant research hotspot that is given to the abundant <a href="/topics/materials-science/sodium" title="Learn more about sodium from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">sodium</a> and low price compared to LIBs [</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib5" name="bbib5" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib5"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[5]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib6" name="bbib6" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib6"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[6]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib7" name="bbib7" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib7"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[7]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib8" name="bbib8" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib8"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[8]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib9" name="bbib9" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib9"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[9]</span></span></a>]. Although SIBs and LIBs have similar intercalation chemistry, compared to Li<sup>+</sup>, the ionic radius of Na<sup>+</sup><span> is relatively large which makes the choice of the <a href="/topics/materials-science/anode-material" title="Learn more about anode material from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">anode material</a> particularly crucial [</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib10" name="bbib10" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib10"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">10</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib11" name="bbib11" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib11"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">11</span></span></a>]. Antimony-based materials have received inclusive interest from researchers because of their outstanding performance in SIBs [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib12" name="bbib12" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib12"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[12]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib13" name="bbib13" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib13"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[13]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib14" name="bbib14" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib14"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[14]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib15" name="bbib15" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib15"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[15]</span></span></a><span>]. <a href="/topics/materials-science/antimony" title="Learn more about Antimony from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Antimony</a> sulfide (Sb</span><sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub><span>), which can accommodate 12 <a href="/topics/materials-science/sodium-ion" title="Learn more about sodium ions from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">sodium ions</a>, possesses a relatively high theoretical capacity (946 mAh/g); therefore, it is considered a suitable anode material [</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib16" name="bbib16" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib16"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[16]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib17" name="bbib17" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib17"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[17]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib18" name="bbib18" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib18"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[18]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib19" name="bbib19" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib19"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[19]</span></span></a>]. Regrettably, when used as a SIB anode material, Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub> undergoes significant volume expansion (364%) in the time of the battery charging/discharging cycles, which is a key issue in practical applications, that not only disrupts the electrode structure but also negatively affects the cycle stability of the batteries [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib20" name="bbib20" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib20"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[20]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib21" name="bbib21" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib21"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[21]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib22" name="bbib22" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib22"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[22]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib23" name="bbib23" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib23"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[23]</span></span></a>].</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0040"><span>It has been demonstrated that the <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/electrochemical-performance" title="Learn more about electrochemical performance from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrochemical performance</a> of Sb</span><sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub><span> materials can be effectively improved by constructing <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/heterojunctions" title="Learn more about heterojunctions from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">heterojunctions</a>, compositing with carbon-based materials, and modulating morphologies [</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib24" name="bbib24" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib24"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">24</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib25" name="bbib25" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib25"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">25</span></span></a>]. Combining with FeS<sub>2</sub> or MoS<sub>2</sub>, the Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub><span> <a href="/topics/materials-science/heterojunction" title="Learn more about heterojunctions from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">heterojunctions</a> can be formed, which enhances the charge transfer and accelerates the ionic diffusion. Besides, compositing with carbon-based materials can alleviate the volume expansion of Sb</span><sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub> during long cycles [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib26" name="bbib26" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib26"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[26]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib27" name="bbib27" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib27"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[27]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib28" name="bbib28" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib28"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[28]</span></span></a>]. Furthermore, modulating morphologies of anode materials with multi-dimensional micro- and nano-structures also has the advantages of improving ionic diffusion and inhibiting volume expansion [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib29" name="bbib29" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib29"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[29]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib30" name="bbib30" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib30"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[30]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib31" name="bbib31" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib31"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[31]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib32" name="bbib32" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib32"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[32]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib33" name="bbib33" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib33"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[33]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib34" name="bbib34" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib34"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[34]</span></span></a>]. In previous studies, Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub> anodes with 3D structure were usually constructed by embedding Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub> into materials with the framework [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib35" name="bbib35" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib35"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">35</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib36" name="bbib36" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib36"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">36</span></span></a>]. However, there are few reports on directly synthesizing Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub> with 3D structures for SIB anode material.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0045"><span>In this study, we synthesized <a href="/topics/chemical-engineering/nanoflower" title="Learn more about nanoflower from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">nanoflower</a> Sb</span><sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub> (NFâ€“Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub><span>) through a <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/hydrothermal-synthesis" title="Learn more about hydrothermal method from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">hydrothermal method</a><span><span> employing <a href="/topics/materials-science/potassium" title="Learn more about potassium from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">potassium</a><span> antimony tartrate and thioacetamide as raw materials in the presence of a <a href="/topics/materials-science/surface-active-agent" title="Learn more about surfactant from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">surfactant</a> (didodecyl dimethyl ammonium bromideï¼ŒDDAB), and further composited it with </span></span><a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/reduced-graphene-oxide" title="Learn more about reduced graphene oxide from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">reduced graphene oxide</a> (rGO) to produce nanoflower Sb</span></span><sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>@rGO (NFâ€“Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>@rGO) to enhance its electrochemical performance. The unique 3D structure improved the Na<sup>+</sup>&nbsp;storage ability of Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub> as expected. SIBs with the material delivered a reversible capacity of 544.8 mAh/g and maintained excellent stability within 200 cycles at a rate of 100&nbsp;mA/g. The as-prepared NFâ€“Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>@rGO composite material may become highly potential for achieving high-performance SIBs in the future.</div></section><section id="sec2"><h2 id="sectitle0040" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">2. Experimental section</h2><section id="sec2.1"><h3 id="sectitle0045" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">2.1. Preparation of NFâ€“Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>@rGO</h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0050"><span>All reagents applied in the study were analytically pure and used directly without treatment. Graphite powder was manufactured into graphite <a href="/topics/materials-science/oxide-compound" title="Learn more about oxide from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">oxide</a> based on a modified Hummersâ€™ method [</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib37" name="bbib37" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib37"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">37</span></span></a><span>]. <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/hydrothermal-synthesis" title="Learn more about Hydrothermal method from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Hydrothermal method</a> was utilized for the preparation of the NFâ€“Sb</span><sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub><span><span>@rGO composite. <a href="/topics/chemical-engineering/deionized-water" title="Learn more about Deionized water from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Deionized water</a> was employed to dilute aqueous suspension of graphite oxide, then sonicated it for 1&nbsp;h for purpose of obtaining a </span><a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/graphene-oxide" title="Learn more about graphene oxide from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">graphene oxide</a><span><span> suspension (0.73&nbsp;mg/mL). After that, 0.1&nbsp;g of DDAB was dissolved in 30&nbsp;mL of the <a href="/topics/materials-science/graphene-oxide" title="Learn more about graphene oxide from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">graphene oxide</a><span> suspension. A 30-min stirring period was followed by the addition of 1&nbsp;mmol of <a href="/topics/materials-science/potassium" title="Learn more about potassium from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">potassium</a> </span></span><a href="/topics/materials-science/antimony" title="Learn more about antimony from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">antimony</a><span> tartrate and 2&nbsp;mmol of thioacetamide, then 60&nbsp;min was continued for stirring. Subsequently, equal portions of the above mixture were transferred into 50&nbsp;mL stainless steel autoclaves lined with <a href="/topics/chemical-engineering/polytetrafluoroethylene" title="Learn more about Teflon from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Teflon</a>, and the entire reaction was processed in the blast drying oven at 180&nbsp;Â°C for 6&nbsp;h. Until the system temperature dropped to the room temperature, the obtained samples were rinsed 6 times with alcohol and deionized water alternately. After washing, freeze-drying was used for the precipitate was at âˆ’80&nbsp;Â°C for 48&nbsp;h, then annealed at 300&nbsp;Â°C for 45&nbsp;min under vacuum, which reduced the graphene oxide. For comparison, NFâ€“Sb</span></span></span><sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub> was synthesized in 30&nbsp;mL of deionized water without the graphene oxide suspension.</div></section><section id="sec2.2"><h3 id="sectitle0050" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">2.2. Material characterization</h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0055">X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were collected on a Rigaku D/max 2500 <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/diffractometers" title="Learn more about diffractometer from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">diffractometer</a><span><span> using Cu KÎ± radiation (Î»&nbsp;=&nbsp;1.5418&nbsp;Ã…) to obtain the crystal structures of the products. Using a Hitachi S-4800 system, electrode morphologies of the fabricated electrodes were observed from the field-emission scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images. On a JEOL microscope (JEM-2010, 200&nbsp;kV), transmission <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/electron-microscope" title="Learn more about electron microscope from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electron microscope</a> (TEM) and selected area </span><a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/electron-diffraction" title="Learn more about electron diffraction from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electron diffraction</a><span> (SAED) observation were implemented. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis was showed using Thermo Fisher Scientific to explore surface features. <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/raman-spectra" title="Learn more about Raman spectra from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Raman spectra</a> were collected with Renishaw RM1000 spectroscopic system employing a Heâ€“Ne radiation source excited at 633&nbsp;nm. The KRZ-S02P thermogravimetric analyzer was used to heat up to 800&nbsp;Â°C at a heating rate of 10&nbsp;Â°C/min starting from room temperature under air atmosphere.</span></span></div></section><section id="sec2.3"><h3 id="sectitle0055" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">2.3. Electrochemical measurements</h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0060">Typically, the working electrode was manufactured by slurry coating method, which was formed from the homogenized mixtures of NFâ€“Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>@rGO/NFâ€“Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>/commercial Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub><span> (active material), acetylene black (conducting additive) and carboxymethylcellulose <a href="/topics/materials-science/sodium" title="Learn more about sodium from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">sodium</a> (CMC, binder) in an 80:10:10&nbsp;wt ratio and deionized water; then a copper foil (current collector) was applied to the slurry and vacuum-dried for 12&nbsp;h at 60&nbsp;Â°C. The average mass loading of the active material for each electrode (14&nbsp;mm in diameter) was typically 1.0â€“1.4&nbsp;mg/cm</span><sup>2</sup><span>. For <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/sodium-ion-batteries" title="Learn more about SIBs from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">SIBs</a>, the electrochemical tests were performed making use of two-electrode coin cells (CR2032), and the working electrodes served as anode and pure Na plate acted as both the counter electrodes using glass fiber as the separator in the batteries. Half-cells were assembled in an argon-filled glove box, in which the concentrations of moisture and oxygen were maintained below 0.1&nbsp;ppm. The electrolyte was a mixed solution composed of 1.0&nbsp;M NaClO</span><sub>4</sub><span> dissolved in <a href="/topics/chemical-engineering/propylene" title="Learn more about propylene from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">propylene</a> carbonate (PC) and ethylene carbonate (EC) (1:1 in volume) with 5&nbsp;wt% fluoroethylene carbonate (FEC) as an additive. Each coin cell was filled with 120&nbsp;Î¼L of the electrolyte using a pipette. Using a programmed battery testing system (Land, CT3001A), galvanostatic discharge/charge and rate capability were measured in the voltage window of 0.01â€“2.50&nbsp;V (vs. Na/Na</span><sup>+</sup><span>). In this experiment, the CHI660E-typed electrochemical workstation was performed to measure <a href="/topics/materials-science/cyclic-voltammetry" title="Learn more about cyclic voltammetry from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">cyclic voltammetry</a> (CV) with a scanning rate of 0.1&nbsp;mV/s between 0.01 and 2.50&nbsp;V (vs. Na/Na</span><sup>+</sup><span>). <a href="/topics/materials-science/dielectric-spectroscopy" title="Learn more about Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy</a> (EIS, with a frequency range of 10</span><sup>5</sup>â€“10<sup>âˆ’2</sup>&nbsp;Hz) was conducted on spectroscopy PARSTAT 2263 system with 5&nbsp;mV perturbation voltage.</div></section></section><section id="sec3"><h2 id="sectitle0060" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">3. Results and discussion</h2><section id="sec3.1"><h3 id="sectitle0065" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">3.1. Characterization</h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0065"><span>Analysis of <a href="/topics/materials-science/x-ray-diffraction" title="Learn more about XRD from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">XRD</a> data revealed the composition and crystalline structure of the synthesized substances. </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig1" name="bfig1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 1</span></span></a>a displays that the characteristics of the NFâ€“Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>@rGO complex are equivalent to those of Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub> with an orthorhombic structure (JCPDS standard No.42-1393). The diffraction peak intensity of NFâ€“Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>@rGO is slightly lower than that of Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub><span> because the surface <a href="/topics/materials-science/amorphous-material" title="Learn more about amorphous from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">amorphous</a> graphene blocks some amount of X-rays [</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib38" name="bbib38" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib38"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">38</span></span></a>]. For further characterization of NFâ€“Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>@rGO, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#appsec1" name="bappsec1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="appsec1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S1</span></span></a> and <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig1" name="bfig1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 1</span></span></a><span>b present <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/raman-spectra" title="Learn more about Raman spectra from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Raman spectra</a> of as-prepared electrodes of NFâ€“Sb</span><sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>@GO and NFâ€“Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>@rGO. The characteristic peaks located at 100â€“400&nbsp;cm<sup>âˆ’1</sup> exhibit the Raman shifts of Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub> [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib14" name="bbib14" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib14"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">14</span></span></a>], and the peak at 252&nbsp;cm<sup>âˆ’1</sup>, which is assigned to the Sbâ€“Sb bond stretching vibration in the S<sub>2</sub>Sbâ€“SbS<sub>2</sub> group, is the strongest [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib39" name="bbib39" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib39"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">39</span></span></a>]. The two broad peaks centered at 1350 and 1580&nbsp;cm<sup>âˆ’1</sup> associate with the characteristic D- and G-band of rGo separately [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib40" name="bbib40" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib40"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">40</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib41" name="bbib41" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib41"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">41</span></span></a>], and the intensity ratio I<sub>D</sub>/I<sub>G</sub><span> reflects the <a href="/topics/materials-science/defect-density" title="Learn more about defect density from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">defect density</a> in the graphene planes. The I</span><sub>D</sub>/I<sub>G</sub> of NFâ€“Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub><span>@rGO was calculated to be 1.18, suggesting that the reduction of <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/graphene-oxide" title="Learn more about graphene oxide from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">graphene oxide</a> introduced more defects into NFâ€“Sb</span><sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>@rGO [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib42" name="bbib42" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib42"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">42</span></span></a>].</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="fig1"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S025405842300545X-gr1.jpg" height="328" alt="Fig. 1" aria-describedby="cap0010"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S025405842300545X-gr1_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (591KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (591KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S025405842300545X-gr1.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cap0010"><p id="fspara0010"><span class="label">Fig. 1</span>. (a) XRD patterns of NFâ€“Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub> and NFâ€“Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>@rGO; (b) Raman spectra of the NFâ€“Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub><span>@rGO; (c) <a href="/topics/materials-science/thermogravimetric-analysis" title="Learn more about TGA from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">TGA</a> profile of the NFâ€“Sb</span><sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>@rGO; (d) Sb 3d and (e) C 1s narrow scan spectra of the NFâ€“Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>@rGO; (f) N<sub>2</sub> adsorption-desorption isotherms of NFâ€“Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub> and NFâ€“Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>@rGO.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0070"><span>According to <a href="/topics/materials-science/thermogravimetric-analysis" title="Learn more about thermogravimetric analysis from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">thermogravimetric analysis</a> (TGA), the rGO content in the composite was approximately 12.2% (</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig1" name="bfig1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 1</span></span></a><span>c). A <a href="/topics/materials-science/x-ray-photoelectron-spectroscopy" title="Learn more about XPS analysis from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">XPS analysis</a> of the as-prepared products was subjected to determine the chemical states of the elements and compositions, and valence state changes for Sb, S, O, and C are exhibited in </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#appsec1" name="bappsec1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="appsec1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S2</span></span></a>. High-resolution spectrum (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig1" name="bfig1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 1</span></span></a>d) displays two peaks at 529.48 and 538.87&nbsp;eV relation with Sb 3d<sub>5/2</sub> and Sb 3d<sub>3/2</sub> that verify the emergence of Sb<sup>3+</sup> in the sample [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib43" name="bbib43" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib43"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">43</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib44" name="bbib44" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib44"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">44</span></span></a>]. In addition, from <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig1" name="bfig1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 1</span></span></a>e and <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#appsec1" name="bappsec1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="appsec1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S3</span></span></a>, the high-resolution spectrum of C is classified as three peaks, which relate to vibrations C<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/dbnd.gif" style="vertical-align: middle;" alt="double bond">C, Câ€“C, and Câ€“O. Clearly, after thermal reduction, a large proportion of the oxygen-containing groups are removed, which explains that why is the peak intensity of Câ€“O considerably lower compared to those of Câ€“C and C<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/dbnd.gif" style="vertical-align: middle;" alt="double bond">C [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib45" name="bbib45" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib45"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[45]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib46" name="bbib46" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib46"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[46]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib47" name="bbib47" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib47"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[47]</span></span></a><span>]. Overall, <a href="/topics/materials-science/antimony-sulfide" title="Learn more about antimony sulfide from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">antimony sulfide</a> and rGO were successfully compounded according to the given analysis results. Then, the surface areas of NFâ€“Sb</span><sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub> and NFâ€“Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>@rGO were investigated based on the N<sub>2</sub> isothermal adsorption-desorption curves. The results are shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig1" name="bfig1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 1</span></span></a>f. The N<sub>2</sub> adsorption-desorption equilibrium curves of NFâ€“Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub> and NFâ€“Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>@rGO are Brunauer-Emmett-Teller isotherms. The specific surface area of NFâ€“Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>@rGO (4.06&nbsp;m<sup>2</sup>/g) is higher than that of NFâ€“Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub> (2.71&nbsp;m<sup>2</sup><span>/g). The contribution of the specific surface area mainly comes from the size of 21&nbsp;nm <a href="/topics/chemical-engineering/mesopore" title="Learn more about mesopores from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">mesopores</a>. The larger specific surface area is beneficial to provide more reactive sites for electrode reactions and enhance the sodium storage capacity of the material [</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib48" name="bbib48" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib48"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">48</span></span></a>].</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0075">The main synthesis steps for NFâ€“Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub> are illustrated in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig2" name="bfig2" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig2"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a>a, and a relevant elaboration of the growth-progress investigation is revealed in the supporting information. The morphologies and microstructures of NFâ€“Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub> and rGO (different content) composite were studied systematically via SEM (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#appsec1" name="bappsec1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="appsec1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Figs. S4 and 5</span></span></a>). From <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig2" name="bfig2" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig2"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a>b and c of the typical SEM images, NFâ€“Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub> has a uniform nanoflower structure with a diameter of 5&nbsp;Î¼m and is accumulated from sheets with a thickness of 50&nbsp;nm. Meanwhile, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig2" name="bfig2" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig2"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a><span>d of the <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/electron-microscope" title="Learn more about TEM from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">TEM</a> image also displays the sheet-like framework of the nanoflowers. The high-resolution TEM (HRTEM) images of NFâ€“Sb</span><sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub> in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig2" name="bfig2" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig2"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a><span>e reveal a lattice <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/diffraction-pattern" title="Learn more about fringe pattern from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">fringe pattern</a> with a d-spacing of 0.3044&nbsp;nm, corresponding with the (121) plane of orthorhombic Sb</span><sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub><span> crystals, which is in accord with the XRD results. The <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/electron-diffraction" title="Learn more about SAED from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">SAED</a> patterns (</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig2" name="bfig2" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig2"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a>f) of NFâ€“Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub> exhibit the diffraction pattern of Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>, suggesting that the Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub><span> <a href="/topics/chemical-engineering/nanoparticle" title="Learn more about nanoparticles from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">nanoparticles</a> were well crystallized. It was also shown via TEM that the NFâ€“Sb</span><sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>@rGO composite possessed a unique structure. As shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig2" name="bfig2" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig2"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a>g, Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub><span> was well encapsulated within rGO (the corresponding <a href="/topics/materials-science/energy-dispersive-x-ray-spectroscopy" title="Learn more about EDS from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">EDS</a> test shown in </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#appsec1" name="bappsec1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="appsec1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S6</span></span></a><span>). The rGO has high <a href="/topics/materials-science/electrical-conductivity" title="Learn more about electrical conductivity from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrical conductivity</a>, which could enhance the ion migration ability. More importantly, the excellent flexibility of the rGO can slow down the volume change of Sb</span><sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub> during electrochemical cycling as the outer coating layer. Consequently, the structural integrity is maintained, and battery performance is improved [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib41" name="bbib41" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib41"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">41</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib49" name="bbib49" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib49"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">49</span></span></a>].</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="fig2"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S025405842300545X-gr2.jpg" height="691" alt="Fig. 2" aria-describedby="cap0015"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S025405842300545X-gr2_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (1MB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (1MB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S025405842300545X-gr2.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cap0015"><p id="fspara0015"><span class="label">Fig. 2</span>. (a) Schematic illustration of the growth process of NFâ€“Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>; (b), (c) SEM image; (d) TEM image; (e) HRTEM image and (f) SAED pattern of the NFâ€“Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>; (g) TEM image of the NFâ€“Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>@rGO.</p></span></span></figure></div></section><section id="sec3.2"><h3 id="sectitle0070" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">3.2. Electrochemical performance</h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0080">Assembling a half-cell with a pure sodium plate as counter electrode and the electrodes composed of active materials, electrochemical performance was assessed for NFâ€“Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub><span><span>@rGO as an <a href="/topics/materials-science/anode-material" title="Learn more about anode material from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">anode material</a> for SIBs. Firstly, typical </span><a href="/topics/materials-science/cyclic-voltammetry" title="Learn more about CV from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">CV</a> curve of NFâ€“Sb</span><sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>@rGO was measured, and <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig3" name="bfig3" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig3"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a>a exhibited the redox behavior, which performed for the initial three cycles between the operating voltage range of 0.01â€“2.5&nbsp;V at 0.1&nbsp;mV/s. At 0.76, 0.40, and 0.24&nbsp;V, three reduction peaks were noticed in the first cathodic scan of the discharge process. The production of solid-electrolyte interface (SEI) film is correlated with the reduction peak at 0.76&nbsp;V [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib50" name="bbib50" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib50"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">50</span></span></a>]. Meanwhile, the cathodic peak at 0.40&nbsp;V is related with the conversion reaction of Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub> (Eq. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fd1" name="bfd1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fd1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">(1)</span></span></a>), in addition, the obvious reduction peak appears at 0.20&nbsp;V corresponding to the alloying reaction between Na<sup>+</sup> and Sb (Eq. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fd2" name="bfd2" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fd2"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">(2)</span></span></a>) [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib51" name="bbib51" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib51"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">51</span></span></a>]. Then the following anodic scan implies the occurrence of dealloying reaction and recovery behavior during the first charge, which includes the extraction of Na<sup>+</sup> from alloy products (inverse process of Eq. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fd2" name="bfd2" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fd2"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">(2)</span></span></a>) at 0.77&nbsp;V and the generation of Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub> (inverse process of Eq. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fd1" name="bfd1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fd1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">(1)</span></span></a>) at 1.49&nbsp;V. Owing to the activation process during the first discharge, the first curve profile is significantly different from those of the following cycles [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib13" name="bbib13" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib13"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">13</span></span></a>]. In addition, CV measurement of NFâ€“Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub> (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#appsec1" name="bappsec1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="appsec1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S7a</span></span></a>) was also implemented, indicating that the main electrochemical process was controlled by Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>.<span class="display"><span id="fd1" class="formula"><span class="label">Eqs. 1</span><span>Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub> + 6 Na<sup>+</sup> + 6 e<sup>âˆ’</sup> â†’ 2Sb + 3Na<sub>2</sub>S</span></span></span><span class="display"><span id="fd2" class="formula"><span class="label">Eqs. 2</span><span>2Sb + 6 Na<sup>+</sup> + 6 e<sup>âˆ’</sup> â†’ 2Na<sub>3</sub>Sb</span></span></span></div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="fig3"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S025405842300545X-gr3.jpg" height="335" alt="Fig. 3" aria-describedby="cap0020"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S025405842300545X-gr3_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (617KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (617KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S025405842300545X-gr3.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cap0020"><p id="fspara0020"><span class="label">Fig. 3</span>. (a) CV curves of NFâ€“Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>@rGO at a scan rate of 0.1&nbsp;mV/s; (b) Galvanostatic charge-discharge voltage profiles measured at a current rate of 100&nbsp;mA/g over the first three cycles; (c) Rate performance of the NFâ€“Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub> and NFâ€“Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>@rGO at various current densities; (d) Comparison of cycling performance at a rate of 100&nbsp;mA/g; (e) EIS of the commercial Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>, NFâ€“Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub> and NFâ€“Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>@rGO.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0085">The electrochemical performance of NFâ€“Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>@rGO was evaluated as an anode material using the initial three-cycle galvanic charge/discharge cycling curves at a rate of 100&nbsp;mA/g from 0.01&nbsp;V to 2.5&nbsp;V, which are exhibited in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig3" name="bfig3" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig3"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a>b. The profile graph can be observed that the platform voltage was in highly consistent with the results of the CV tests. Moreover, the initial discharge and charge specific capacities of NFâ€“Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>@rGO were 838.5 and 609.0 mAh/g, respectively, yielding a high initial coulombic efficiency (ICE) of 72.6%. Compared to the NFâ€“Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub> anode, with initial discharge and charge capacities of 826.4 and 400.1 mAh/g and ICE of 48.4% (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#appsec1" name="bappsec1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="appsec1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S7b</span></span></a>), NFâ€“Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub><span>@rGO showed significantly improved electrochemical performance. Based on the above results, the high reversible capacity depends mainly on the reaction between the <a href="/topics/materials-science/sodium-ion" title="Learn more about sodium ions from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">sodium ions</a> and the residual oxygen-containing functional groups in rGO, that is the formation of a well-performing SEI film [</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib52" name="bbib52" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib52"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">52</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib53" name="bbib53" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib53"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">53</span></span></a>].</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0090">Furthermore, the rate capabilities of the NFâ€“Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub> and NFâ€“Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>@rGO electrodes in various current densities from the operating voltage of 0.01&nbsp;Vâ€“2.5&nbsp;V are displayed in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig3" name="bfig3" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig3"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a>c. Every five cycles, the current density was increased by degrees at 50, 100, 200, 500, 1000 and 2000&nbsp;mA/g. By comparison, NFâ€“Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>@rGO displayed a better rate performance, which delivered the specific capacity of 433.4 mAh/g even at a high current rate of 2000&nbsp;mA/g and the capacity retention was 71.6% (605.2 mAh/g, 50&nbsp;mA/g). Moreover, while the current density is recovered to 50&nbsp;mA/g, NFâ€“Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>@rGO could still maintain a capacity of 559.4 mAh/g, demonstrating excellent rate performance compared to that of NFâ€“Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>, which may be due to provide fast transport channels for sodium ions to improve the high-rate performance of the material [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib54" name="bbib54" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib54"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">54</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib55" name="bbib55" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib55"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">55</span></span></a>].</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0095">Except for the rate performance, the long-cycle performance was measured at 100&nbsp;mA/g to examine the advantages of NFâ€“Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>@rGO. Batteries with NFâ€“Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub> and commercial Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub> were assembled and tested in the same situation. From the second cycle, the commercial Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub> of <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig3" name="bfig3" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig3"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a>d showed a significant capacity fade to only 50% of its initial capacity following 20 cycles due to volume expansion in the process of discharging, which brings out the powdering of the active material and gives rise to the active material falling from the current collector [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib56" name="bbib56" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib56"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">56</span></span></a>]. In contrast, under the same test conditions, NFâ€“Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub> prepared in this study showed a clear capacity decline at approximately 70 cycles, which was also caused by the inevitable volume expansion of the Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub> electrode material. Notably, NFâ€“Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub> did not experience a significant capacity degradation during the first 40 cycles owing to its unique microstructure. Specifically, the NFâ€“Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub> has a three-dimensional (3D) layered structure, which can disperse stress and slow down the material pulverization caused by the volume expansion of the Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub> material [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib33" name="bbib33" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib33"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">33</span></span></a>]. Therefore, the electrode structure is prevented from being destroyed, resulting in good device stability. Additionally, the 3D structure provides much larger specific surface areas, which increases the contact area with the electrolyte, and shortens the Na<sup>+</sup> diffusion path, leading to better cycling performance [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib36" name="bbib36" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib36"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">36</span></span></a>]. In comparison with the capacity of the second cycle, the capacity retention of NFâ€“Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>@rGO was 75.4% after 200 cycles. Another NFâ€“Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub><span>@rGO battery with the same preparation parameters was assembled and tested for electrochemical performance to demonstrate the reproducibility of the <a href="/topics/materials-science/device-fabrication" title="Learn more about device fabrication from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">device fabrication</a> (</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#appsec1" name="bappsec1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="appsec1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S8</span></span></a>). Besides, long cycle performance at high current densities of 500&nbsp;mA&nbsp;g<sup>âˆ’1</sup> was also tested in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#appsec1" name="bappsec1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="appsec1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S9</span></span></a>. Excellent performance is due to the result of the incorporation of rGO, NFâ€“Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>@rGO was not pulverized during the sodiation/desodiation process; instead, it had a more stable electrode structure [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib57" name="bbib57" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib57"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">57</span></span></a>].</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0100"><span><a href="/topics/materials-science/dielectric-spectroscopy" title="Learn more about EIS from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">EIS</a> measurements were implemented to study the electrochemical behavior of NFâ€“Sb</span><sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>@rGO. The tested data (dots) and the fitted curves (lines) of the EIS measurement are shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig3" name="bfig3" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig3"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a>e. There is a good agreement between the tested data and the fitted curves. Furthermore, each Nyquist plot consisted of one semicircle and a straight line. The former is in connection with the charge transfer resistance (Rct) between the electrode material and the electrolyte at the high frequency, the latter corresponds to diffusion resistance of sodium ions in the electrode at the low frequency. Obviously, the Rct of NFâ€“Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>@rGO (49.74&nbsp;Î©) is significantly smaller than those of NFâ€“Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub> (139.23&nbsp;Î©) and commercial Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub> (155.22&nbsp;Î©), confirming that the addition of rGO reduces the electronic resistivity of the electrode and suppresses side reactions.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0105">Next, the diffusion process in the NFâ€“Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>@rGO electrode was investigated by CV measurements to evaluate the sodium storage mechanism of NFâ€“Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>@rGO in the various scanning rates range of 0.1â€“5&nbsp;mV/s (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig4" name="bfig4" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig4"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a>a). CV profiles at the various scanning rates can further quantitate the diffusion-controlled vs. surface-controlled ratio. The peak currents and scan rates tended to follow a power-law pattern according to the CV curves [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib58" name="bbib58" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib58"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">58</span></span></a>].<span class="display"><span id="fd3" class="formula"><span class="label">Eqs. 3</span><span><em>i</em>&nbsp;=&nbsp;<em>av</em> <sup><em>b</em></sup></span></span></span>Here, <em>i</em> is the peak current; <em>a</em> and <em>b</em> are adjustable constants; <em>v</em> is the scanning rate. The value of <em>b</em> can change between 0.5 and 1, which determines the sodiation/desodiation type. The surface-capacitance dominates electrochemical process if the value of <em>b</em> is close to 1, whereas the value of <em>b</em> approaching 0.5 means a representative diffusion-controlled faradaic process. This implies that for SIBs, the transfer of Na<sup>+</sup> occurs only in the outer layer the active material, proving a dynamic advantage over diffusion inside the active material [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib59" name="bbib59" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib59"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">59</span></span></a>]. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig4" name="bfig4" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig4"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a>b shows a logarithmic plot of the peak currents versus scan rates (log(<em>i</em>) vs. log(<em>v</em>)). After fitting, the <em>b</em>-values for the anodic (0.41&nbsp;V) and cathodic peaks (1.25&nbsp;V) of NFâ€“Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>@rGO are obtained of 0.72 and 0.77, respectively, which means that the electrochemical processes corresponding to the two peaks are jointly controlled by diffusion-controlled faradaic and capacitance-dominated processes.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="fig4"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S025405842300545X-gr4.jpg" height="417" alt="Fig. 4" aria-describedby="cap0025"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S025405842300545X-gr4_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (583KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (583KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S025405842300545X-gr4.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cap0025"><p id="fspara0025"><span class="label">Fig. 4</span>. (a) CV curves of the NFâ€“Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>@rGO at different scan rates; (b) Plots of log(<em>i</em>) versus log(<em>v</em>) at different voltages in charge and discharge; (c) Capacitive contribution to the capacity at a scan rate of 1&nbsp;mV/s; (d) Capacitive contribution to the capacity at different scan rates.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0110">In addition, there is another equation that describes the relations between the peak current (i) and the potential (V) for further quantitative analysis of the pseudocapacitive contribution [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib60" name="bbib60" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib60"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">60</span></span></a>];<span class="display"><span id="fd4" class="formula"><span class="label">Eqs. 4</span><span><em>i</em>(<em>V</em>)&nbsp;=&nbsp;k<sub>1</sub><em>v</em>&nbsp;+&nbsp;k<sub>2</sub><em>v</em><sup>1/2</sup></span></span></span>where k<sub>1</sub> and k<sub>2</sub> are the variable parameters in the equation; k<sub>1</sub><em>v</em> and k<sub>2</sub><em>v</em><sup>1/2</sup> are on behalf of the surface-capacitance-dominated and the diffusion-controlled faradaic process each on its own. Therefore, calculating both <em>k</em><sub><em>1</em></sub> and <em>k</em><sub><em>2</em></sub> allows one to quantify the contribution of capacitance from the surface-capacitance-dominated process at increasing scanning rates of 0.1, 0.2, 0.5, 1.0, 2.0, and 5.0&nbsp;mV/s [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib61" name="bbib61" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib61"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">61</span></span></a>]. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig4" name="bfig4" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig4"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a>c shows that the contribution of surface-capacitance-dominated process was 36% at 1.0&nbsp;mV/s. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig4" name="bfig4" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig4"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a>d illustrates the contribution to the charge at various scan rates. With increasing scan rate, the contribution of the surface-capacitance-dominated process gradually improves, indicating that the storage of sodium ions results from rapid interface reactions or double-layer charge at high scan rates. This also demonstrates that the charge storage of NFâ€“Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>@rGO composites at high currents is dominated by interfacial charge storage. Generally, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig4" name="bfig4" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig4"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a> shows that the Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>@rGO composite has a relatively high contribution of pseudocapacitance, which further proves that the rGO composite can accelerate the kinetic process of the reaction. Thus the Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>@rGO composite can be able to cycle 200 cycles stably without significant capacity decay.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0115">Furthermore, galvanostatic current intermittent titration technique (GITT) measurement was performed to examine the kinetics of Na storage in the composite NFâ€“Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>@rGO (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig5" name="bfig5" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig5"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 5</span></span></a>). The battery was discharged/charged for 30&nbsp;min at 550&nbsp;mA/g served as a pulse period, then staying quiet for 60&nbsp;min as an interval time was achieved to allow complete relaxation to the quasi-equilibrium potential. From <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig5" name="bfig5" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig5"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 5</span></span></a>, it can be seen that the potential can quickly recover from the relaxation potential to the resting potential at the end of resting, which proves that the electrode has a fast response. During the charging process, the difference between the resting and relaxation voltages becomes larger, indicating that the polarization of the anode material is more serious, probably due to the gradual conversion of Sb to Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>. It is not difficult to find that the GITT curve has a similar shape to that of the aforementioned galvanostatic charge-discharge curve, even under continuous charge and discharge conditions, potentially because of the good ionic and electronic conductivities of NFâ€“Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>@rGO [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib62" name="bbib62" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib62"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">62</span></span></a>]. The polarization phenomena are nearly the same, demonstrating that the chemical reactions of NFâ€“Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>@rGO anode material are highly reversible. In addition, the overpotential of the desodiation and sodiation processes was relatively small, indicating that Na<sup>+</sup> could diffuse rapidly in the NFâ€“Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>@rGO composites. These results strongly demonstrated that the sodiation/desodiation kinetics of the NFâ€“Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>@rGO composite are rapid and reversible [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib63" name="bbib63" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib63"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">63</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib64" name="bbib64" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib64"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">64</span></span></a>].</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="fig5"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S025405842300545X-gr5.jpg" height="289" alt="Fig. 5" aria-describedby="cap0030"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S025405842300545X-gr5_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (285KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (285KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S025405842300545X-gr5.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cap0030"><p id="fspara0030"><span class="label">Fig. 5</span>. GITT curves of the NFâ€“Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>@rGO.</p></span></span></figure></div></section></section><section id="sec4"><h2 id="sectitle0075" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">4.
